awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Optoelectronic Probes of Interlayer Electron-Hole Pair Multiplication in Atomic Layer Semiconductor Heterostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical Description: Nearly all household and commercial solar energy panels employ photovoltaic devices. These devices operate through an important microscopic process: an individual particle of light (a photon) is absorbed to create an individual pair of charge carriers (an electron-hole pair). Electron-hole pairs are then separated and collected to generate power. The efficiency of a photovoltaic device is governed by a simple competition: light energy is either converted into waste heat or useful electronic power. Ultra-thin materials may tip the balance in this competition by simultaneously limiting heat generation, while increasing the electronic power. This project explores ultra-thin materials to understand a fundamental process known as electron-hole pair multiplication. In this process, an individual photon is converted into multiple electron-hole pairs, thus dramatically increasing the device efficiency. Understanding such processes, together with improved designs that push beyond the theoretical efficiency limits, is expected to have a broad significance with regard to designing new ultra-efficient photovoltaic devices. A synergistic project within this research is the integration of undergraduate education across all levels by introducing the growing importance of Data Science methods in fundamental research and applied science. A key aspect of this project focuses on facilitating scientific exposure to underrepresented groups through intensive training and development, as well as raising awareness of the opportunities for underrepresented groups in professional scientific careers.

Technical Description: The principal investigator and his research team are investigating a novel class of ultra-thin semiconductor photocells, which may exhibit highly efficient interlayer electron-hole pair multiplication by a single photon. The research efforts are addressing several fundamental challenges: (1) control and enhancement of photocurrent power conversion efficiency due to electron-hole pair multiplication, (2) reduction of electronic and thermal energy dissipation through efficient charge carrier multiplication and collection, and (3) direct measurement of the dynamics of multiplied interlayer electron-hole pairs. To accomplish the research objectives, the team utilizes versatile optoelectronic methods and approaches to uncover new phenomena to advance the current state of nanofabrication, spatio-temporal spectroscopy and condensed matter measurements. By developing innovative nano-optoelectronic devices and utilizing ultrafast photoexcitation spectroscopies, the PI is exploring a highly efficient mechanism of light energy harvesting, in which energy relaxation occurs predominantly through the electronic degree of freedom. The multi-disciplinary research of this project has a potential to broaden the understanding of electron-hole pair behavior in quantum-confined materials and two-dimensional heterostructures, and to guide new design principles for next-generation photovoltaic devices.

por.por_cntn:
Almost two decades ago, researchers investigating the properties of very thin graphite flakes used transparent adhesive tape to exfoliate an atomically thin film of carbon atoms - called graphene - from a larger chunk of graphite. This represented the ultimate limit in ultra-thin materials. Since this discovery, nanotechnologists have developed rapidly evolving techniques to engineer novel devices from atomically thin materials such as hexagonal boron nitride (hBN) and transition metal dichalcogenides. These materials can be stacked vertically into layered structures that combine the properties of the constituent materials in unusual ways.

This project has focused on combining and engineering completely new ultrathin materials to create designer properties that result from a new type of engineering called length scale engineering. Length scale engineering involves tuning the electronic, optical, and physical properties of new materials by structuring the critical device length scales at or below the electron wavelength. In loose analogy to optical metamaterials - in which ultra-small structure affects large scale optical properties - engineering sub-wavelength structure in these new so-called quantum metamaterials may give unprecedented access to electronic properties, allowing us to engineer all of the fundamental properties of these new material systems.

In several published works funded by this program, the PI examined these new materials (as well as new design strategies) for their future application in ultra-high efficiency light sensing and light harvesting devices. In the earliest major work within this project, the PI discovered a liquid-like phase of electrons at room temperature. In optoelectronic semiconductors, electrons and holes behave as a dilute gas of hydrogen-like molecules (excitons). When the density of excitons is sufficient, this gas of electrons and holes may spontaneously merge into a liquid. Prior to the PI?s work, this spontaneous condensation had been observed only under extreme conditions of very low temperatures and very high excitation powers. The observation of the electron-hole liquid at room temperature was the sought-after goal of nearly 30 years of research. Later, in 2020, the PI discovered the first quantitative explanation of why plants are green, a study largely influenced by the contrast between photosynthesis and modern quantum materials for light harvesting applications. The PI showed how light-harvesting antennae can be tuned to maximize power conversion efficiency by minimizing excitation noise, thus providing a unified theoretical basis for the observed wavelength dependence of absorption in green plants, purple bacteria, and green sulfur bacteria. Most recently, by stacking atomically thin semiconductors, the PI engineered a completely new type of device that harnesses both vibrational and electronic energy to absorb near infrared light (see Illustration), an important part of the solar light spectrum. This device - the vibronic photodiode - exhibits unusual physics that is often observed in photosynthesis yet had not been previously harnessed in solid state devices.

Beyond new discoveries and inventions, this project was impactful in other important ways. As active scientists at the intersection of physics, biology, and materials science, it is important to evaluate how we can build diversity within our research groups, in our classrooms, and in our scientific communities. Funding through the NSF has enabled the PI to develop new course work and new teaching paradigms that are synchronistic with efforts in Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion. This project has had a remarkably broad impact on K-8 (grade and middle school) students who have taken part in the PI?s recent outreach efforts, as well as young kindergartners and first graders who have been involved in outreach events. These students, who are at a pivotal point in their education, will make up the future of the US?s populace in an era in which facts are only marginally valued by society. The PI?s outreach program has been an effort to teach the value of factual investigation of the world and how ideas from science can affect their lives. The PI has incorporated numerous undergraduate and graduate students into the lab, all of whom were first-generation students, and many of whom were from underrepresented groups. The PI has a strong sense of pride in the socioeconomic diversity in his lab and continues to commit all available resources to supporting Diversity, Equity, and Inclusion in the sciences.

From these innovative approaches, diverse research avenues have been initiated, and the PI?s work has had an exceptionally broad impact. However, many challenges lie ahead. The new materials and metamaterials are increasingly complex, and understanding their behavior involves probing large parameter spaces. Conventional experiments may not be sufficient for comprehensive understanding of complex behavior. These new materials promise to change the world we live in, but also require new and innovative approaches to take full advantage of their potential.
